artworkData.title: Vernet, Triumph of Aemilius Paulus
artworkData.description:
Vernet’s painting, which depicts a ruler of ancient Rome proudly parading enslaved captives and other spoils of war through the city streets, exemplifies the popularity of Neoclassicism during the era of the French Revolution. It also suggests how Neoclassicism may have been linked to proslavery and pro-colonial ideas held by its owners, among them the wealthy financier Jean-Joseph de Laborde.


Current Location: The Met

provenanceEvents.title: 1. Vernet’s Ambitious Debut in Rome (1789)
provenanceEvents.text: Vernet painted his ambitious Triumph of Aemilius Paulus in 1789, while he was a student of the French Academy in Rome. This enormous canvas (so large that he had to rent a bigger studio in Rome to complete it) was intended to cap off Vernet’s splash debut on the Paris art scene. He included it as the centerpiece of his portfolio of works for admission to the Academy, and he showed it at the Salons of 1789 and 1791. Neoclassical paintings of Roman history were major attractions at the Salons of the 1780s (we can see several in Martini’s print of the Salon of 1787), and scholars often link these paintings to calls for revolution and reform, specifically to the desire to metaphorically liberate French citizens from an oppressive absolutist regime. Vernet’s painting, however, depicts slavery in a different sense. It represents a famed triumphal procession of a Roman consul who had conquered a territory and brought back 150,000 enslaved captives, and thus seems to celebrate colonial domination and enslavement as fundamental to the glory and prosperity of Rome—and perhaps to France as well, given the fact that the question of maintaining slavery in the colonies was being hotly debated at this time. Salon critics noticed that Vernet included several ancient monuments depicting enslaved captives that had not been built at the time this ancient procession had taken place (and he also exaggerated the representation of captives on these monuments), implying that Vernet may have wanted to stoke these Revolutionary debates about slavery—but from a colonial rather than a metaphorical perspective.
provenanceEvents.imageSource: Pietro Antonio Martini (after Johann Heinrich Ramberg), Exhibition at the Salon du Louvre in 1787, 1787. Etching and engraving, 32.2 x 49.1 cm. The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Elisha Whittelsey Collection, The Elisha Whittelsey Fund, 1949
provenanceEvents.imageAlt: Pietro Antonio Martini (after Johann Heinrich Ramberg), Exhibition at the Salon du Louvre in 1787, 1787. Etching and engraving, 32.2 x 49.1 cm. The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Elisha Whittelsey Collection, The Elisha Whittelsey Fund, 1949

provenanceEvents.title: 2. Purchased by Laborde (1791)
provenanceEvents.text: The possible proslavery subtext of Vernet’s painting is supported by the fact that it was bought by Jean-Joseph de Laborde (1724-94), an extremely wealthy financier who was one of the largest landowners in Saint-Domingue, and who had personally overseen the trafficking of more than 10,000 enslaved Africans to the colony. Laborde acquired the painting in 1791, as he and other slave traders, despite the Revolution, were continuing to prosper. His son, François Laborde de Méréville (1761-1801), became a deputy for the new Revolutionary government (he appears near the center of David’s Oath of the Tennis Court) and was a member of the proslavery lobby that argued for the need to maintain slavery in the colonies. The story behind this painting suggests that scholars should rethink Neoclassicism as a style associated mainly with liberty and reform and acknowledge how some Neoclassical artworks endorsed a vision of slavery in the ancient world, one that 18th C. colonial patrons used to model and justify their own practices.
provenanceEvents.imageSource: Jacques-Louis David, The Oath of the Tennis Court, 1791. Pen, ink, and wash on paper, 66 x 101.2 cm. Musée du Louvre, on deposit at the Musée National des Châteaux de Versailles et de Trianon. © GrandPalaisRmn (Château de Versailles).
provenanceEvents.imageAlt: Jacques-Louis David, The Oath of the Tennis Court, 1791. Musée du Louvre, on deposit at the Musée National des Châteaux de Versailles et de Trianon.

provenanceEvents.title: 3. Seized and Returned (1794–1797)
provenanceEvents.text: In 1794, the same year that slavery was temporarily abolished in France, Revolutionary forces confiscated the Triumph of Aemilius Paulus from the Parisian hôtel where Laborde was living on the rue d’Artois, right around the same time that Laborde himself was guillotined. Three years later, the painting was restituted to the family by the state and returned to Laborde’s widow, Rosalie de Nettine de Laborde.
provenanceEvents.imageSource: Jean-Jacques Champin, Hôtel of the Laborde family (later known as the Hôtel Lafitte), 19th Century. Lithograph, 17.9 x 22 cm. Musée Carnavalet, Paris (CC0 1.0).
provenanceEvents.imageAlt: Jean-Jacques Champin, Hôtel of the Laborde family (later known as the Hôtel Lafitte), 19th Century. Musée Carnavalet, Paris.

provenanceEvents.title: 4. Back in the Vernet Family (1822)
provenanceEvents.text: By 1822, Vernet’s triumphalist painting had made its way into the collection of the artist’s own family and had become the property of Carle’s son Horace, who continued both his father and grandfather’s tradition of engaging with colonial themes in art. He would later become France’s chief painter and propagandist in connection with the monarchy’s invasion and colonization of Algiers, while also fashioning himself as an Orientalist art collector as evidenced by his self-portrait of 1835.
provenanceEvents.imageSource: Horace Vernet, Self-Portrait with a Pipe, c. 1835. Oil on canvas, 47 x 39 cm. Hermitage Museum, Saint Petersburg, Russia. Image source: WikiArt.
provenanceEvents.imageAlt: Horace Vernet, Self-Portrait with a Pipe, c. 1835. Hermitage Museum, Saint Petersburg.

provenanceEvents.title: 5. Vernet’s Triumph in Gilded America (1906)
provenanceEvents.text: By the late nineteenth century, the Triumph of Aemilius Paulus—like so many old regime French paintings acquired by Gilded Age tycoons—ended up in the U.S. in the hands of Heber R Bishop (1840-1902), an art collector and trustee of The Metropolitan Museum of Art, who made his first fortune through a sugar refinery business in Cuba. Bishop later invested in many banking, railroad, steel, and mining companies, and he used the profits to amass an extensive collection of artifacts from Asia, Mexico, Alaska, and New Zealand that he donated to the Met and to the American Museum of Natural History. After he died, his wife’s brother-in-law, Darius Ogden Mills, acquired Vernet’s painting and gave it to the Met in 1906.
provenanceEvents.imageSource: Photograph of the ballroom of Heber R. Bishop’s mansion at 881 Fifth Avenue, New York City, late 19th Century. Image in the public domain.
provenanceEvents.imageAlt: Photograph of the ballroom of Heber R. Bishop’s mansion, late 19th Century.

nodes.bio: French painter (1758–1836), known for large-scale Neoclassical works. Father of Horace Vernet.
Extremely wealthy financier and major landowner in Saint-Domingue. Oversaw the trafficking of 10,000+ enslaved Africans.
Son of Jean-Joseph de Laborde, deputy in the Revolutionary government and member of the proslavery lobby.
Confiscated the painting in 1794, during the temporary abolition of slavery in Revolutionary France.
Wife (and later widow) of Jean-Joseph de Laborde; retrieved the painting after Revolutionary confiscation.
Son of Carle Vernet. Became France’s chief painter and propagandist for the colonial invasion of Algiers.
American sugar-refining magnate (1840–1902) and trustee of the Met. His collection included Vernet’s Triumph.
Brother-in-law of Heber R Bishop. Acquired Triumph of Aemilius Paulus after Bishop's death and donated it to the Met.
Major American art museum in New York City, recipient of Vernet’s painting in 1906.
